item.title: COD’s Toxicity Levels Plummet as Black Ops 6 Approaches
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/cod-toxic-black-ops-6/

Activision’s enforcement teams continue to innovate and find ways to reduce the levels of ‘online toxicity’ across the Call of Duty ecosystem. Most recently, the platform saw the introduction of ToxMod, an AI-driven digital moderation engine that automatically detects abusing comms and reports it.

It was recently revealed that since ToxMod was rolled out in June 2024, ‘disruptive voice chat’ has dropped by 43% since the start of the year.

The Old Ways

Any Call of Duty veteran will baulk at the idea of having an AI representative moderate their voice and text chats. It can be argued that toxicity and trash-talking are woven into the very fabric of Call of Duty. It doesn’t take much to get a veteran to rant about ‘today’s players not surviving in MW2 Search lobbies’.

Activision’s ToxMod technology has reportedly brought about a decrease of a whopping 67% in repeat offenders using the game’s voice chat function to abuse other users. It was referenced that in July 2024, one month after the deployment of ToxMod, 80% of players who were issued an enforcement did not re-offend.

ToxMod works silently in the background to monitor all communications running through Call of Duty, acting on them and reporting any malfeasance to a centralised body of human representatives. If needed, action will then be taken.

It has been claimed that ToxMod is so intelligent that it can figure out the difference between friendly and edgy banter and genuine insults, identifying the difference by analysing the tone and sentiment of what someone is saying. It’s clever enough to identify the severity of a comment based on the response from other users.

It’s not a bad thing that it exists, but it’s going to slow down those hot-headed Call of Duty players with a penchant for slamming other players midway through an intense Search and Destroy series.

Will Black Ops 6, which is due to hit the market on October 25, be the first toxicity-free Call of Duty game ever?

Do you think this is a necessary feature in Call of Duty? Let us know on the Insider Gaming forum.

item.title: GTA Online’s New Zombie Mode Brings 1.2 Million Players to North Yankton
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/gta-online-zombie-mode-ludendorff/

It was a few days ago that Rockstar revealed this year’s Halloween-themed event in GTA Online – Ludendorff Cemetary Survival. It’s a blast from the past that delivers GTA 5 fans a zombie survival mode that they’ve been craving for more than a decade, and it has gone down remarkably well with the community.

In recent hours, the concurrent player count on the Ludendorff Cemetry Survival mode peaked at over 1.2 million users. That’s a testament to the fact that after more than a decade, Grand Theft Auto fans are still very hungry for more content.

Fight Them Back

The Ludendorff Cemetary Survival mode is one of the most engaging events in GTA Online’s ten-year history. In this mode, players must band together and unite against waves of bloodthirsty zombies, making use of a range of weapons and power-ups to take on hordes of the undead.

It’s a clear callback to Red Dead’s Undead Nightmare DLC, which featured a mode exactly like this one.

According to GTAO Stats, the number of plays for the Ludendorff Cemetary Survival map has soared over the weekend, hitting 2.6 million plays in total – 1.2 million of which were unique. It’s not clear just how reliable this data is, but a cursory glance at social and streaming platforms will tell you all you need to know.

It could be said that GTA Online and Grand Theft Auto 5 are in their twilight phase now, preparing to wind down and be replaced for the next decade or so by Grand Theft Auto 6. It has been almost a year since the first trailer for GTA 6 was released, and fans are still chomping at the bit for more information about the game.

We may see a new trailer revealed at The Game Awards in December – but don’t quote me on that.

Did you give the Ludendorff Cemetery Survival mode a run yet? Let us know on the Insider Gaming forum.

item.title: Secret Level Trailer Leaks, Revealing Several Cast Members
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/secret-level-trailer-leak-cast/

Secret Level was unveiled at the recent Gamescom Opening Night Live ceremony, with Blur Studio lifting the lid on an ambitious project incorporating several recognisable franchises. Secret Level is an animated series in which every episode is based on a different game: God of War, Unreal Tournament, Warhammer, and so on.

We’ve had a few teaser trailers released in the last couple of months, but most recently, a leaked ‘work-in-progress’ trailer emerged online, revealing several key cast members, including Arnold Schwarzenegger.

Blown Wide Open

The leaked Secret Level trailer, which surfaced from a Telegram server and was circulated by MP1st, showcases more of the franchises that have found a spot in the project. It’s a long list, and the potential of Secret Level is almost unparalleled – there are so many video game series to draw from to populate the universe.

In the trailer, the vocal talents of several high-profile actors are revealed:

  • Arnold Schwarzenegger
  • Patrick Schwarzenegger
  • Kevin Hart
  • Heaven Hart
  • Keanu Reeves
  • Gabriel Luna
  • Arianna Greenblatt
  • Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje
  • Michael Beach
  • Emily Swallow
  • Claudia Domit

Some parent-child partnerships are cropping up in Secret Level, it seems. Arnold Schwarzenegger is joining forces with his son, while Kevin Hart’s daughter makes an appearance in the series.

Here’s one of the previously released trailers for Secret Level:

We don’t have long to wait until the finished trailer is released online – the show itself premieres on Prime Video on December 10, and it promises to offer a little something to everyone, regardless of the kind of games that you enjoy.

Are you looking forward to checking out Secret Level when it’s released in December? Let us know on the Insider Gaming forum.

item.title: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Frieza
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/dragon-ball-sparking-zero-episode-battles-guide-frieza/

Dragon Ball Sparking Zero’s Episode Battles is a new game mode that allows players to not only revisit the iconic moments from the popular anime series but also delve into unexplored storylines. This Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles will help you better understand all the different branching paths for Frieza. 

Players should know that there are two types of branches: alternate endings and paths. Completing these branches can earn you extra rewards, such as additional Zeni, XP, items and more. Specific scenarios also play Sparking! Episodes which are original cutscenes created for these unseen moments. This guide will highlight all the branching paths and alternate endings for Frieza’s Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles and explain how to unlock them. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Future Trunks

Immortal Body

The first alternate ending for Frieza’s Sparking Zero Episode battles arrives during ‘A Blast from the Past’ mission. The alternate ending is called ‘Immortal Body’, and to unlock it, you will need to defeat all the fighters before Goku collects enough energy to launch a Spirit Bomb. 

If you defeat all the fighters quickly, Goku will have no one to help him while collecting energy for the Spirit Bomb. Hence, he will have no option but to participate in hand-to-hand combat. Frieza overpowers him easily and kills his friends and his son on Planet Namek. Once everything is out of the way, Frieza searches for the Dragon Balls and wishes to be immortal. Goku dies before his friends, so he doesn’t turn Super Saiyan in this timeline. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Piccolo

Fall of the Saiyans 

The next Sparking Zero alternate ending for Frieza’s Episode Battles arrives during the ‘Legendary Super Saiyan’ Mission. You must complete a hidden objective to unlock the ‘Fall of the Saiyans’ ending. Players must defeat Frieza before he shows his Full Power transformation to trigger this ending. 

If you beat Goku without transforming into Frieza’s Full Power Transformation, a new Sparking! Episode is unlocked. In this new scenario, Goku is cornered by Frieza and uses one last Kamehameha to finish the job. However, that’s not enough to defeat Frieza, and Goku dies. 

Frieza finally gets what he wants and manages to wipe out the Saiyan race. He declares himself the strongest in the universe, expanding the Frieza Force’s hold all over the cosmos. Frieza also loses interest in becoming immortal after defeating Goku. However, he does start training as he doesn’t want to drop from the top spot. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Saiyan Saga

Rematch with Goku 

The next alternate ending for Frieza’s Sparking Zero episodes can be unlocked during the ‘Frieza Descends on Earth’ mission. You must complete the hidden objective to unlock the ‘Rematch with Goku’ ending. The hidden objective is to defeat Future Trunks before the match ends. 

A new scenario will play out if you can defeat Future Trunks before the match ends. Trunks is defeated in the battle against Frieza, which leads to Goku getting ambushed as soon as he returns from Yardrat. Frieza manages to beat Goku, overcoming the power of a Super Saiyan. After beating Goku, he kills every mortal on Earth and extends his reign of terror across the galaxy. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Android/Cell Saga

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Gohan Buu Saga

Frieza Joins the Fray

The last one is an entire branching storyline for Frieza called ‘Frieza Joins the Fray’. To unlock this path, players must defeat Goku and Vegeta before Frieza’s Golden Transformation is undone during the Frieza Revived mission. 

A new Sparking Episode plays if you can defeat Goku and Vegeta before Frieza’s Golden transformation is undone. In this timeline, Frieza overpowers Goku and Vegeta and is almost about to end their life along with the planet. That’s when Beerus steps in, stopping Frieza from destroying Earth.

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Buu Saga 

Frieza’s Conditions 

Frieza questions why a Destroyer God would protect life, to which Beerus replies, stating he still has use for the planet. Beerus asks Frieza whether he is thankful that he achieved this new form because of the people on Earth. To which Frieza replies that it is true; this Golden Form wouldn’t have been achievable if he didn’t have the Saiyans to defeat. 

Frieza accepts not to destroy Earth but applies two conditions for doing so. The first one requires Beerus not to interfere with any Frieza Force activities. The second condition is for Frieza to use Earth’s Dragon Balls to revive the fallen Frieza Force members. Beerus agrees to both conditions, adding that Frieza is now the strongest person in the universe after him. 

Frieza now starts training his revived soldiers, which includes all the minions Goku and Vegeta had defeated in the past, even the Ginyu Force. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Super Saga

Tournament of Power 

Sometime after, Beerus approaches Frieza, asking him to join the Tournament of Power. Frieza has a condition again; this time, he wants to choose some of the team members for Universe 7. You can choose between Dodoria and Zarbon, King Cold, The Ginyu Force, and Cooler. 

The choice really doesn’t change much. Universe 7 always ends up winning the tournament; only the battles leading up to them are different, along with some interesting exchanges between the characters. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero: Gohan Black Guide

Choosing your Teammate(s)

  • Choosing Dodoria and Zarbon will lead you to clash with Kakunsa, Bergamo and Frost. Dodoria and Zarbon will defeat the rest of the enemies, and Frieza will have the energy to defeat Jiren to save Universe 7. 
  • If you choose Cooler, you fight against Hit. After winning against the Ultimate Hitman, the brothers dominate the Tournament of Power, defeating all other Universes. 
  • If you choose King Cold, he will try to recruit the Saiyans from Universe 6 to the Frieza Force. You will fight Cabba, Kale, Caulifla, and the fused Kefla on this path. 
  • Lastly, if you choose the Ginyu Force, Frieza will recognise a similarity between them, the Pride Troopers and Universe 2’s Ribrianne, Kakunsa and Rosie. The similarity is none other than their fighting poses. Frieza proceeds to insult the posers and then ends up fighting Ribrianne and Toppo.

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Vegeta Android/Cell Saga 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Vegeta Buu Saga

If you are new to the game, check out the Attack, Movement and Defense guides. These are all the branching paths and alternate endings for Frieza’s Episode Battles in Dragon Ball Sparking Zero. What are your thoughts on it? Let us know in the comments or our new community forum!

item.title: Cyberpunk 2077 With DreamPunk 2.1 Mod and Path Tracing Is Almost Indistinguishable from Reality in New 8K Video
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/cyberpunk-2077-dreampunk-path-tracing-8k/

Cyberpunk 2077 continues to be one of the best-looking open-world games released in recent years, thanks to mods that enhance the game's visuals to unprecedented levels.

A few days ago, NextGen Dreams shared a new 8K resolution video showcasing the game running with path tracing and the DreamPunk 2.1 mod, one of the most demanding graphics configurations ever created. The mod's new version overhauls the graphics configuration, indirect lighting, light diffusion, LUT saturation, and much more to offer incredibly realistic visuals that look incredibly realistic.

As development of Cyberpunk 2077 has concluded, it will be up to modders to continue improving the game. Still, CDPR is still providing minimal support to its game, as last month, official support for AMD FSR 3 was added to the game. Sadly, CDPR went with an older version of the upscaler which doesn't deliver many improvements over FSR 2.

Cyberpunk 2077 is now available on PC, PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, and Xbox One. You can learn more about the Phantom Liberty expansion and the massive 2.0 update which overhauled much of the game by checking out Alessio's review.

Cyberpunk 2077: Phantom Liberty builds upon what was an already great game to deliver more fantastic storytelling (with a spy thriller theme, this time around), exciting combat, and very high-quality side content. The perk tree overhaul is a major improvement to progression, and additions like vehicle combat and the overhauled police system are very welcome, albeit not game-changing. If you've been holding out on Cyberpunk 2077 until now, you'll find a huge game with over 120 hours of quality content and an incredibly immersive game world to literally lose yourself in. On top of that, it's by far the most beautiful and technically advanced game available if you have the hardware for it (PC and RTX 40 GPU).

item.title: Phantom Thief Angels: Twin Angel – Labyrinth of Time and World – Re:light announced for PC
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gematsu.com/2024/10/phantom-thief-angels-twin-angel-labyrinth-of-time-and-world-relight-announced-for-pc
  • PC

Due out in Q4 2024 in English, Japanese, and Simplified Chinese.

ALTERCIWS has announced Phantom Thief Angels: Twin Angel – Labyrinth of Time and World – Re:light, a remastered version of the August 25, 2011-released PSP visual novel Phantom Thief Angels: Twin Angel – Labyrinth of Time and World. It will launch for PC via Steam in Q4 2024 with English, Japanese, and Simplified Chinese language support. A demo is available now.

Here is an overview of the game, via ALTERCIWS:

About

The Sammy-supervised PSP classic Phantom Thief Angels: Twin Angel – Labyrinth of Time and World gets HD remaster!

The remaster features full HD visuals, remastered sound effects, multilingual support, and other optimizations for a modern visual novel experience.

Kiichi Kanoh, the director and writer of the original PSP game, returns as executive producer.

Story

Haruka Minazuki and Aoi Kannazuki are ordinary schoolgirls at St. Cherine School. But by night, they transform into the righteous heroines, “Phantom Thief Angels: Twin Angels”! Balancing school life with their nighttime battles against a massive conspiracy, they work alongside Kurumi Hazuki, Tesla, and Nine to thwart the evil organization The Black Fund.

Though they successfully reclaim the stolen artifact “Tears of an Angel,” their victory is short-lived. The artifact is stolen again, leading them on a new adventure where they encounter two unfamiliar Phantom Thief Angels. Discover the secrets behind the birth of “Twin Angels” and witness the power of their unwavering bonds.

Key Features

  • Full High-Definition Visuals – The original game’s visuals have been remastered for modern displays, upgrading the resolution from 480×272 to 1920×1080.
  • Optimized Narrative Experience – For a more immersive story experience, the original slot-battle segments have been removed. The game is now optimized for seamless text-based gameplay. (Please note: Due to production constraints, character voices are not included in this remaster.)
  • Player Choices and Branching Narrative – The story branches significantly based on the player’s choice of protagonist: Haruka or Aoi. This choice affects everything from minor dialogue changes to entirely different scenes.
  • Multilingual Support – Play the game in Japanese, English, or Simplified Chinese.

item.title: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Future Trunks
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/dragon-ball-sparking-zero-episode-battles-guide-future-trunks/

Dragon Ball Sparking Zero’s Episode Battles are this series’s new story mode, allowing players to experience the anime’s iconic moments and explore some never-before-seen scenarios. This Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles guide will help you better understand all the different branching paths for Future Trunks. 

Future Trunks’s Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles have several branching storylines, and two offer a set of Super Dragon Balls each. Players should know that completing these branches will reward them with additional rewards, such as Zeni, Xp, and other items. This guide will highlight all the branching paths for Trunks’ Episode Battles and explain how to unlock them. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Saiyan Saga

Shining Hope 

The first branching storyline for Future Trunks arrives during the ‘Twisted World Mission’ when you’re battling Zamasu and Black Goku. To unlock the ‘Shining Hope’ path for Future Trunks, you will need to reduce Zamasu’s health quickly, and a great way to do that is by using combos until you can go in Sparking! Mode, then riddle him punches until the last Ki bar is left, and that’s when you use Future Trunks’ Super Attack. 

If you manage to beat both characters in the given time, a new scenario triggers. In this scene, Trunks doesn’t stay back to fight Zamasu and Black Goku to help Vegeta and Goku leave. Instead, he returns with them and learns about the Evil Containment Wave from Piccolo. 

Future Trunks then returns to the timeline and must battle the immortal Zamasu. Trunks ends up trapping him in a container with the Evil Containment Wave if you defeat him and then joins Goku and Vegeta to fight Black. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Android/Cell Saga

Desire to Protect 

However, Black seems unfazed by this, stating that he alone is enough to carry out the Zero Mortal plan and that he can always find a replacement Zamasu with the help of the time rings. Now, you must defeat Black Goku in his Rose transformation to finish Zamasu’s reign of terror. 

Future Trunks and Black have a colossal beam clash, and Vegeta joins in to back his son. Vegeta then provides some final motivational words that push Trunks over the edge. Trunks wins the battle, and finally, a mortal overcomes a god. 

Trunks hands over Zamasu’s container to Universe 10’s Supreme Kai Gowasu and then lives peacefully in his timeline while keeping up with his training. We never see Fused Zamasu in this timeline, as Trunks traps him before Black and Zamasu can Fuse. This means we don’t see Super Vegito either. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Buu Saga

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Super Saga

Trunk’s Choice

This alternate storyline is available after the main events of Future Trunks’s Sparking Zero Episode Battles are over, after the ‘Trunks’s Choice’ mission. After defeating Black and Zamasu, Trunks returns to Goku and Vegeta’s timeline, and Bulma asks him to stay back. You will have the choice of ‘Staying in the Present’ or ‘Go Back to Your Timeline’; choosing the latter will follow the events from the anime, and Trunks’s Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles will conclude. 

If you decide to Stay Back, Future Trunks will ask Vegeta to train him one last time, and Gohan and Piccolo will join this training. This mission is called ‘To Become Strongest in the Universe’, and Trunks has to showcase his powers to all three fighters to complete it. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero: Gohan Black Guide

To Become Strongest in the Universe

There are two alternate endings to this Future Trunks’ mission, one where you only showcase your powers to the three fighters and then return to your timeline a bit stronger than before. The second ending is unlocked when you showcase your power quickly to Vegeta, Gohan and Piccolo, which means getting through them much faster. If you succeed, a new path is unlocked, called Inherited Pride. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Gohan Cell Saga

Inherited Pride 

Once unlocked, a new cutscene plays, where Gohan admits Future Trunks has outclassed him in terms of power and even with his Potential Unlocked, he still might not be able to beat Trunks. After this exchange with Gohan, Future Trunks decides to stay in the present for some more time, and a little while later, Bulma gets pregnant.  

This is also the same time the Tournament of Power arrives, so Goku tries to convince Vegeta to join the Universe 7 team. He refuses at first as he doesn’t want to leave Bulma alone, but after Whis delivers the baby instantaneously with his angelic powers, Vegeta agrees to join the team.   

Future Trunks embraces his sister, Bulla, for the first time during this moment. He also overhears a conversation between Gohan and Yamcha, where it’s revealed that the tournament winner can make a wish with the Super Dragon Balls. This information piques Trunks’ interest. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Gohan Buu Saga

Future Trunks Join the Tournament of Power

Future Trunks then decides to join the Tournament of Power, hoping to use the Super Dragon Balls to revive his fallen family and friends from his timeline. He trains with Vegeta to learn how to fight without his sword, as weapons are prohibited. Finally, the day of the tournament arrives. 

In this scenario, Gohan is still leading Universe 7, and just like last time, Goku and Vegeta leave the pack to find the stronger fighters. Here, you are presented with another choice, either ‘Stay with Gohan’ or ‘Help Vegeta’, and both paths provide a set of Super Dragon Balls each, so once you finish the first path, make a Super Shenron wish and then return for the second path. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Gohan Super Saga

Help Vegeta

If you decide to help Vegeta, you must fight against the Saiyans of Universe 6, and Cabba and Trunks have a meaningful interaction here. The next battle is with Kale and Caulifla, and once you defeat them, Toppo will jump in. 

A new Sparking! Episode plays where Vegeta arrives to help out Trunks, and then the father-son duo give it their all against Toppo. They manage to overcome Toppo’s God of Destruction powers, and at the same time, Goku and Android 17 sacrifice themselves to get Jiren out. As Vegeta and Trunks were the last fighters on the stage, Universe 7 won. 

When the time comes to make a wish with the Super Dragon Balls, Trunks realizes that bringing back all the destroyed universes was the only path here, thanks to Vegeta instilling that into him. Completing this path will provide you with the ending of Inherited Pride. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Vegeta Android/Cell Saga 

Stay with Gohan 

If you choose to stay with Gohan, you must confront Kale and Caulifla again. This time, Kale goes berserk and fights Goku. After that battle, you will have to defeat Toppo and Dyspo. They will ambush Future Trunks, but Android 17 and Android 18 will come to his aid. At this point, Trunks realizes these Androids are very different from those in his timeline, and they have compassion for the fighters, their families, and their universes.

Android 18 sacrifices herself to remove Dyspo, and Jiren gets rid of Kefla. Future Trunks and Vegeta are able to take care of Toppo; however, Vegeta is knocked out by Jiren later. Now, it’s Jiren versus Earth’s fighters. An intense battle begins, but Earth’s warriors fall short against Jiren. In the dying moments, Gohan sacrifices himself to save Trunks, which makes Future Trunks angry enough to take the fight to Jiren. 

Trunks, Goku, and Android 17 are able to beat Jiren in the end, thanks to Android 17’s brave move. The match ends, and Future Trunks wishes to restore all the universes and then returns to his timeline. By Staying with Gohan, players received the Embarking Toward Tomorrow Ending. Moreover, as Trunks fights in the tournament, there’s no need for a 10th fighter, and Goku does not need to ask Frieza for help. 

You must unlock both endings, Inherited Pride and Embarking Toward Tomorrow, to receive the two sets of Super Dragon Balls. Players should note that Super Dragon Balls cannot be stacked, so use the wish before collecting the next set.

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Vegeta Buu Saga

item.content:encoded:

Steam's next, er, Next Fest is almost upon us, offering "hundreds of amazing demos of games that haven't even released yet".

Launching tomorrow and running until 21st October, Steam Next Fest features a host of vertical slices to let you try before you buy, including demos of upcoming games like Antonblast, Microtopia, Mini Royale, The Precinct, and a game that lets you be a bar-tending vampire, Blood Bar Tycoon.

Other games offering free-to-play demos are Sulfur, Battle Train, Call of Boba, Knights in Tight Spaces, Luma Island, and the intriguingly entitled Is This Game Trying to Kill Me? (Yes. Yes it is).

For more, check out the brief teaser above, and/or head on over to the Next Fest landing page. The fest goes live at 6pm UK time (10am PT) on Monday 14th October.

"No matter what kind of game you're in the mood for, developers from all over the world are showcasing their demos during Next Fest, looking for feedback from players and hoping for wishlists," Steam teases.

Ahead of new California legislation requiring storefronts to make it clear customers are only buying a license for digital content rather than outright owning it, Steam has implemented a message at the point of purchase doing just that.

item.title: Larian's director of publishing calls out Baldur's Gate 3 CE scalpers for "making people sad"
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/larians-director-of-publishing-calls-out-baldurs-gate-3-ce-scalpers-for-making-people-sad

Baldur's Gate 3's director of publishing, Michael Douse, has called out scalpers for "making [people] sad".

Although the official website still shows the physical PC and PS5 collector's editions for Baldur's Gate 3 were priced at £217 (€260) before they were promptly snapped up, scalpers are trying their luck and listing the collector's editions on auction sites for thousands of pounds.

Appending an image that showed someone trying to flog their collector's edition for £2.9K (€3.4K), Douse said he "understand[s] how commodity works", but stressed that the point of releasing collector's editions like this is "to make someone happy".

"Hate scalpers, man," Douse said on X/Twitter (thanks, TheGamer). "I understand how commodity works, but this CE isn't a commodity, it's designed to make someone happy, not rich.

"If you're buying it to trade, all you're doing is making someone sad."

Hate scalpers, man. I understand how commodity works, but this CE isn’t a commodity it’s designed to make someone happy, not rich. If you’re buying it to trade, all you’re doing is making someone sad. pic.twitter.com/vtH2CX3OhQ

— Very AFK (@Cromwelp) October 12, 2024

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

The post prompted over a hundred replies, many from fans who were equally frustrated.

"That someone is me," lamented one commenter.

Last month brought news that Baldur's Gate 3 was a step closer to getting the series' classic real-time with pause combat thanks to one enterprising modder, but there was plenty to chew through even before official modding became a thing.

item.title: More former ZA/UM devs have set up another studio, but they are "definitely not" working on a Disco Elysium sequel
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/more-former-zaum-devs-have-set-up-another-studio-but-they-are-definitely-not-working-on-a-disco-elysium-sequel

"It is time to break away from the past and start a new chapter."

Yet another Disco Elysium legacy project has been announced.

Summer Eternal is a new studio from Argo Tuulik, a former ZA/UM developer cited as having co-created Disco Elysium's worldbuilding. It is the third ZA/UM-adjecent outfit to have used Disco Elysium's fifth anniversary on 11th October to announce their next steps.

If you're struggling to keep track of everything, you're not alone, but this appears to be the fifth - fifth! - Disco Elysium offshoot, with three of them all announced on the same day. The others include Longdue, a new independent studio comprising staff from Disco Elysium studio ZA/UM, and Dark Math Games, a studio describing itself as a "breakaway group from the original development team of Disco Elysium".

Writer and designer Robert Kurvitz also established Red Info in 2023 with artist Aleksander Rostov. And then there's ZA/UM itself, of course.

Tuulik was the last remaining writer to have contributed to Disco Elysium to have been let go earlier this year following the cancellation of a Disco Elysium standalone expansion.

Tuulik has teamed up with fellow Disco Elysium writers Olga Moskvina and Dora Klindžić, as well as voice actor Lenval Brown, senior concept artist Anastasia Ivanova, designer Michael Oswell, and Gamechuck's former MD, Aleksandar Gavrilović.

"We must be living at the dawn of a cultural Golden Age, when like mushrooms after rain the companies promising 'the next Disco Elysium' are popping up every hour on the hour," Summer Eternal said in a statement to IGN.

"It's a sure sign that the fifth anniversary of the release of this monumental game is approaching, and every corporation wants a piece of the fortune.

"However, often forgotten in this money lust are the creatives themselves, first instrumentalised for press releases and afterwards underpaid, silenced, bullied, sued, abused... But it is all of us - the creatives, the workers, the players - who should be holding control over the means of our creation and who should be celebrated on this day.

"Therefore, we announce today our own vision of a worker-owned co-operative, a complex structure that will ensure that not only moneylenders but every worker, every creative, even every player, has a seat at the table."

Interestingly, Tuulik is keen to stress that this project will not be a Disco Elysium sequel.

"It will definitely not be a Disco Elysium sequel!" Tuulik said. "It is time to break away from the past and start a new chapter.

"It will be a completely new setting and story with new mechanics. But end of the day, we are who we are, and RPGs are what we will make - do what you will with it :)"

"I believe that the last time around, we made something genre-breaking," Tuulik added. "Discipline-transcending. Something completely new. I am not ready to give up on that.

"The lessons learned, skills developed, experience forged -- for five fucking years, I've been waiting to put them to use. So we went back to the drawing board with one goal in mind - let's do it fresh from the start, but this time let's not fuck each other the moment the checkered flag drops. It makes the entire mankind look bad."

This seeming rivalry is likely the result of unrest at the studio following the release of Disco Elysium, including a lawsuit, reports of toxic behaviour and IP theft, and layoffs after a standalone expansion was reportedly cancelled, leading to an extremely public legal spat.

item.title: Diablo IV: Vessel of Hatred Is An Expansion Worth Committing To
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/diablo-iv-vessel-of-hatred-expansion-tips-walkthrough-1851670301

With the release of Vessel of Hatred, Diablo IV has seen its most significant changes since its original launch in June 2023. Adding a completely new region, Nahantu, along with a wealth of added characters and modes and a brand-new story, the expansion pack is the very definition of a game changer. But it goes even further than that, bringing in entirely new ways to upgrade items, a revamp of the World Tiers, new animal-morphing classes, and a new level cap. However, we meet change without fear, offering a litany of guides to get you up to speed.

For instance, Diablo IV now has NPC Mercenaries you can hire to come with you on your brawling, but you’re only going to find them by following a specific series of quests. Then there are those Spiritborn classes that let you pick between being able to possess the powers of a Jaguar, Eagle, Gorilla, or Centipede…Wait, centipede? No, we’ve checked, that’s definitely correct—and apparently one of the best choices for end-game content.

And this all follows on from piles of massive changes earlier this year, which saw the introduction of loot-fest The Pit, a new way to improve loot called Tempering, the addition of Mythic Uniques, and Infernal Hordes to battle. It’s mayhem!

But worry not, as here we’ve collected every guide we’ve published for Diablo IV’s big changes, which will see you flying toward the new level cap in no time at all.

It’s time, once again, for The Wanderer to suit up and go dungeon crawling. This time, in the new Vessel of Hatred expansion for Diablo IV, you’re in pursuit of poor, tormented Neyrelle in the Hate-ridden lands of Nahantu. Much as I’d like to tell you that there’s a nice handy little pamphlet titled, “So, You Just Sent An Innocent One-Armed Girl Into The Heart Of A Jungle Full Of Demons,” I’m sorry to say it’s just not the case. — Justin Clark

Read More

Runewords, and not “Rude words” like you thought, are a new mechanic in Diablo IV: Vessel of Hatred, letting you add new customizable, conditional buffs to your equipment. These socketable items can be dropped by enemies and chests across Diablo IV—here’s how to find them and use them. — Brian Barnett

Read More

Blizzard’s continued improvements for Diablo IV have introduced many new, mechanics, among them the incredibly useful Tempering. Once you begin collecting powerful gear, particularly Legendary, Unique, and Ancestral-rarity items, Tempering is one of the new major ways you’ll push their power even higher. MORE POWER! Here’s how. — Brian Barnett

Read More

With Diablo IV’s expansion, Vessel of Hatred, comes a new array of features, among them the new NPC buddy system, the Mercenary. Starting with Raheir, who you meet early on in your adventure into Nahantu, you’ll be able to travel with CPU-controlled allies, each with skill trees of their own. They’re here to help you through the dangers of Sanctuary! Here’s everything you need to know about Mercenaries. — Brian Barnett

Read More

In addition to a brand new story, tons of quality-of-life improvements, many new mechanics, and even some new endgame dungeons to enjoy, Diablo IV: Vessel Of Hatred also adds a new class; the Spiritborn. — Brian Barnett

Read More

At launch, Diablo IV felt barebones. It was lacking essential quality-of-life features and entertaining end-game content. Well, that’s slowly changing with each passing season, as Blizzard works to satiate the terrifying maws of level 100 players. So welcome to The Pit, which completely changes how many farm gear upon reaching the max level in the ARPG. — Brandon Morgan

Read More

Diablo 4 Season Five has brought us the ability to craft Mythic Unique items, which can be an absolute game-changer for those of us who want to get our hands on insane gear early on. Now, this won’t come cheap, but with a little gold and effort, you can have decent gear relatively quickly. — Samantha Giambra-Plaisance

Read More

item.title: Huge Game Freak Leak Reveals Future Project Data and Pokémon Source Code
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/game-freak-leak-pokemon-code/

Game Freak, a Japanese development studio founded in 1989 and best known for the Pokémon series of games, has suffered from a monumental leak that has seen past, present, and future projects blown wide open. This staggering breach reportedly occurred in August 2024, but it’s only now that the data is surfacing online.

The Game Freak leaks have revealed an estimated 1 TB of data, spanning everything from the source code for older titles to the codenames for upcoming Pokémon games.

Gigaleak

In a report first published by Nintendo Life, it was claimed that Game Freak had suffered from a massive leak that had seen hundreds of confidential files broadcast online. Now, Game Freak has published a statement confirming that the breach is accurate, stating that 2,606 employees were impacted.

The firm has stressed that the vulnerability that led to the leak has already been patched up, but the data is changing hands online – and there’s no getting it back.

One of the most tantalising pieces of information to come from the leak concerns the next generation of Pokémon games. In the files, references to ‘K’ and ‘N’ are revealed, along with a project codenamed ‘Synapse’, which some users have claimed is a Pokémon MMO being pieced together in collaboration with another, unnamed studio.

Retro fans have started poring over leaked source code for DS-era Pokémon games like Black and White 2, HeartGold, and SoulSilver. These particular leaks have caused never-before-seen images and cut assets to surface. Some of these images concern concept art for starter Pokémon, and characters that never saw the light of day.

For the full breakdown of leaked Pokémon characters, check out PokeLeaks on Reddit.

Elsewhere, eagle-eyed gamers have uncovered references to Legends ZA and even some details about what’s coming next for Switch 2.

Even now, this story continues to develop.

item.title: Sony Warned 2024 Would Be Light But PS5 Still Has The Best Games
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/sony-warned-2024-would-be-light-but-ps5-still-has-the-best-games

ISSUE NO. 3

Despite a lack of first-party games, PlayStation is still the place to play great games.

This is the latest guest column from Push Square, the voice of the PlayStation community, offering passionate, in-depth coverage and insight into the world of Sony. Its goal is simple: to keep you informed, engaged, and part of the conversation surrounding all things PlayStation.

Sony sparked discontent among the PlayStation fandom in February this year when it said during an earnings call there’ll be no sequels or updates to “major existing franchise titles” on the PS5 before March 2025. With the platform holder keeping its content roadmaps close to its chest, the comments were largely taken out of context and many assumed this would be a lean year for the company’s new-gen console.

While it’s true this has been a fairly quiet year for PS Studios, it’s been anything but light on the games front. At the time of writing, my three Game of the Year frontrunners are Astro Bot, Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth, and Metaphor: ReFantazio and the PS5 is the only platform where you can play all three. Other possible contenders for awards include Silent Hill 2, Helldivers 2, and Black Myth: Wukong – all console exclusives.

There seems to be a sentiment on social media that a game doesn’t count unless it comes from a wholly owned first-party studio, but PlayStation has done a particularly good job of working with partners to keep its portfolio packed this year.

Stellar Blade is a great example. It collaborated with Korean developer Shift Up to help bring the NIKKE: Goddess of Victory creator’s console debut to market and in my opinion is another game in contention for an end of year gong. Rise of the Ronin, a similar partnership with legendary studio Team Ninja, may have received a cooler critical reception but it’s currently ranked 17th in IGN’s ongoing Game of the Year user poll, proving it was a hit with fans.

The nauseating number of remakes and remasters may not be to everyone’s taste, but it’s easy to forget The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered launched this year and tagged a 90 critical average on aggregators Metacritic and Open Critic. And while many rolled their eyes at the rumours around Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered, a $10 upgrade fee and re-recorded dialogue and motion capture mean it’ll almost certainly attract positive reviews as well.

Not everything PlayStation has touched has turned to gold. Its complete misreading of the market with first-person shooter Concord will go down in history

Of course, not everything PlayStation has touched this year has turned to gold. Its complete misreading of the market with first-person shooter Concord – a competent albeit uninspiring affair – will go down in history after getting axed after two weeks. And yet for all the talk of its live service initiative stumbling, it launched the fastest-selling game in PS Studios history with Helldivers 2, an online co-op smash that, despite benefitting from a simultaneous PC launch, has outpaced juggernauts like Marvel’s Spider-Man 2 and God of War Ragnarok.

It’s been a quietly colossal year for PS5 then, and you get the sense the best is yet to come. The company’s largely kept its blockbusters close to its chest but 2025 should see the release of Ghost of Yotei and Death Stranding 2: On the Beach, with Marvel’s Wolverine waiting in the wings. These are the “major existing franchise titles” the Japanese giant was referring to in that aforementioned investor call.

Many may still argue this has been a light year for PS5 but the catalogue of content Sony has amassed paints a very different picture. The most exciting thing is that it’s successfully filled the time while its first-party teams continue to cook. A huge second-half to the generation now awaits.

Sammy Barker is the Editor of Push Square. He’s been living and breathing the wonderful world of PlayStation for decades now – and has the tattoos to prove it. You can find him on @_get2sammyb.

item.title: Now we can all wake up like Mario
item.content:encoded:
https://www.theverge.com/2024/10/13/24268065/nintendo-alarmo-money-electric-onedrive-mastodon-installer

Hi, friends! Welcome to Installer No. 56, your guide to the best and Verge-iest stuff in the world. (If you’re new here, welcome, so psyched you found us, and also you can read all the old editions at the Installer homepage.) 

This week, I’ve been reading about Bill Lawrence’s TV shows and the massively powerful crypto lobby and the wild world of plankton, listening to Ed Helms narrate the excellent Snafu podcast, playing an alarming amount of both Balatro and Retro Goal, trying to get back in the habit of making overnight oats, and taking every single one of my phone calls with the excellent mic on the Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses. 

I also have for you the coolest alarm clock I can remember, a splashy new Bitcoin documentary, a new monster-taming game people love, a tiny but amazing Google Docs update, and much more. Not the busiest and most exciting week of all time, if I’m honest, but still lots of fun stuff to get to. Let’s do it.

(As always, the best part of Installer is your ideas and tips. What are you playing / reading / watching / baking / steeping in teapots this week? What should everyone else be into, too? Tell me everything: installer@theverge.com. And if you know someone else who might enjoy Installer, tell them to subscribe here.)

Installer

/ A weekly newsletter by David Pierce designed to tell you everything you need to download, watch, read, listen to, and explore that fits in The Verge’s universe.

The Drop

  • Alarmo. Leave it to Nintendo to build the most charming alarm clock of all time. No, it’s not the high-tech new gadget some people were hoping for. But a super configurable sleep tracking clock that uses Mario noises and retro animations to get your butt out of bed? I’m obviously sold.
  • Money Electric: The Bitcoin Mystery. Another day, another splashy reveal that “we’ve found Satoshi Nakamoto!” Color me deeply, deeply skeptical. But even that aside, this doc does a good job of arguing that Nakamoto — and Bitcoin in general — matters.
  • Microsoft OneDrive. OneDrive has always been, like, fine. But if Microsoft really has made it faster, improved search, and finally shipped a more photos-focused mobile app, it might finally be a worthy competitor to Google Drive and Dropbox. (Low bar, but hey.)
  • Mastodon 4.3. I’ve found it difficult in recent months to really care about Mastodon, which just seemed like it wasn’t ready to be the next big thing. But I think this update, meant to make the platform easier to use but especially meant to make it easier to find people to follow, is pretty exciting.
  • Miraibo Go. People keep comparing this open-world monster-taming game to Palworld —  because it appears to be super fun and bonkers and also because it doesn’t not look like Pokémon, you know? Either way, I anticipate seeing a lot of people capturing Miras this weekend.
  • “Forums Are Still Alive, Active, And A Treasure Trove Of Information.” Chris Person, a writer at Aftermath and friend of The Verge, is right: if you want the real real on almost anything, the best place to go is a forum. And he put together a truly epic list of great forums, which I will be spending too much time in for the foreseeable future.
  • Piece By Piece. Even if you don’t care at all about Pharrell Williams, you should watch a few minutes of this Morgan Neville-directed doc, which is entirely animated with Legos. (If you’re going to do that… maybe wait ’til it hits streaming.) The trailer alone makes me want to watch hours of this style.
  • Goodnotes. If you’re the write-by-hand type, Goodnotes is one of the best apps out there. And it’s cool to see the company bring AI to the mix — it’s doing some of the same search, handwriting improvement, and equation-solving stuff that is so cool in Apple Notes.
  • Dookie Demastered. The silliest, most delightful thing of the week: Green Day took its 30-year-old masterpiece of a record and tried to make it work on, like, an electric toothbrush. Am I willing to pay $79 for a Big Mouth Billy Bass that plays the song “Basket Case”? OF COURSE I AM.
  • Google Docs tabs. This is one of those tiny organizational things — splitting a Google Docs doc into tabs instead of just a billion pages — that is going to make my life so much easier. Now can Google just make the mobile app good? Please?

Screen share

Out of all the people at The Verge, no one is better at introducing me to new stuff and teaching me how to use that stuff than Barbara Krasnoff. She’s a reviews editor here at The Verge and also does a ton of work on how-tos and roundups and helping tell everyone about all the best technology everywhere. (She recently turned me back onto UpNote, just to name one — and she’s right, it’s delightful.)

So Barbara tries everything, but what does she actually use? I asked her to share her homescreen to find out. Here it is, plus some info on the apps she uses and why:

The phone: It’s a Pixel 6. I know this may go against the tech enthusiast philosophy of “the latest and greatest,” but I tend to hold on to my phones as long as they work (or break — I’ve been known to drop one or two). I believe that Android 15 will be its last OS update, so I’ll probably have to bite the bullet and get a new phone next year when Android 16 shows up.

The wallpaper: This is a photo I took last year in Owego, New York, where a very close friend grew up. It’s the Susquehanna River at sunset.

The apps: Maps, Contacts, Google Voice, Slack, Chrome, Google Home, Google Photos, Google Drive, Files, Google Play Store, Phone, Messages, Gmail, Camera, Assistant.

The icon labeled “LISTEN” goes to a webpage with a recording of Bob Fosse directing Liza Minnelli in the original Broadway production of Chicago, which gives you some idea of the kind of theater nerd I am.

The second screen has all the other apps that I use on a day-to-day basis, divided into groups. (Or used to use — there are some there that I haven’t opened for a long time and really need to delete.) The Tody app was supposed to motivate me to clean my home, but unfortunately, it hasn’t worked as well as I’d hoped. Smart Tools is a bunch of handy apps (like a mirror, a ruler, and a distance calculator) in one neat package.

I’ve got one more screen that has apps I’m currently experimenting with, but that can change on a day-to-day basis, so I don’t think it counts.

I also asked Barbara to share a few things she’s into right now. Here’s what she sent back:

  • Current media obsessions include Agatha All Along, The Great British Bake Off, and rewatching Doctor Who. We’re just finishing the Peter Capaldi era and haven’t yet decided whether to proceed to the Jodie Whittaker era or go back to one of the old Whos, like Tom Baker. I’m really eager to see the latest season of Slow Horses. I read the book it was based on a couple of months ago, but we don’t currently subscribe to Apple TV Plus, so I’ll have to wait.
  • I’m almost finished with Lev Grossman’s The Bright Sword, which is yet another retelling of the King Arthur legend. Grossman is on my long list of favorite authors, and this is a great example of his skill.
  • I’m not much of a gaming person, but I have been battling two friends for several years on Words With Friends 2 — we’re pretty much equally matched. And I love crossword puzzles, Wordle, etc. So I guess I’ll have to adjust that to say I’m a word gaming person.
  • Finally, I’m trying to recover my childhood fluency in Yiddish using Duolingo. Not the greatest experience, because it uses a modern Hasidic pronunciation that is much different than the older Eastern European dialect I grew up with. Still, I’m pushing ahead with it.

Crowdsourced

Here’s what the Installer community is into this week. I want to know what you’re into right now as well! Email installer@theverge.com or message me on Signal — @davidpierce.11 — with your recommendations for anything and everything, and we’ll feature some of our favorites here every week. For even more great recommendations, check out the replies to this post on Threads.

“Reading Jason Pargin’s I’m Starting to Worry About This Black Box of Doom. A dark, funny commentary on modern culture.” – Matthew

“Strudel. I’ve used a lot of live-coding languages and frameworks, but so far, this one has worked the best for me. It’s a really fun and immediate way of making music compared to a traditional DAW. It has nothing to do with generative AI, it’s not just a prompt engine, it’s basically just another interface for doing what you’d normally do with Ableton or whatever.” – Tom

“I recently stopped using TickTick, as I’ve been trying to reduce my subscriptions. I wanted to try living off of Apple Reminders. I feel like it’s 90 percent of the way there. Luckily, for the last 10 percent, I think I found the perfect app with GoodTask! It’s only for Apple devices, but it basically supercharges Reminders by adding stuff like customization, a better interface, and a calendar. Best of all, it’s a one-time purchase of $10!” – John

“I picked up the Native Union (Re)Classic Case for my iPhone 16 Pro, and this thing is nice.” – Joe

“Superlocal Maps has been a lot of fun and really useful. My favorite feature is Fog of World, which keeps track of where you have and haven’t ‘discovered’ in the world, similar to discovering locations in games like Fortnite but in the real world. Outside of that, it’s got some really cool Perplexity / ChatGPT-like search capabilities for finding places near you, e.g., ‘What are some coffee shops nearby that have free Wi-Fi?’ or ‘What are some dog-friendly parks I can visit in Sydney?’” – Harry

“The new 3-in-1 Ninja Luxe espresso machine has been keeping me overcaffeinated. Weight-based dosing ensures your beans are consistently ground, it evaluates the shots you pull to recommend changes to grind size, and the automated frother makes it easy to get right, too. Great for someone like me who cares about their coffee but isn’t overly fussy about it.” – Scott

“I was looking for a good idle / incremental game to play in down moments, and Idle Iktah has totally fit the bill. I can enjoy mobile games a bit too much sometimes and have to be cautious about getting caught in addictive gameplay loops. Iktah is right in the sweet spot of engaging but not consuming, with charming PNW-inspired pixel art.” – Emmett

“Apple’s native apps have gotten good enough to be your main productivity stack. Forever Notes is an elegant and fresh look at configuring Apple Notes as a sophisticated note program. As a longtime and happy Obsidian user, I’m impressed with how well this configuration works. It’s also very well documented and supported.” – Jim

“I am an old paying Overcast user and can confirm that the new Swift version is finally working fine.” – Gabriel

Signing off

I have to admit something: I have become a spreadsheet person. I’ve avoided Excel, Google Sheets, and anything else that looks like rows and columns for as long as I can remember, but over the course of this year, I’ve worked on an unusual number of big team projects — the sort that require a lot of people to know what’s going on at any given time — and man, you just can’t beat the efficiency of a good spreadsheet. I’m barely scratching the surface, features-wise, but I’m hooked on how easy it is to build a calendar, a project tracker, or just a good ol’ budget system in a spreadsheet. Who needs awesome optimized apps! Give me rows and columns! I hate that I’ve become this person, but I fear there’s no going back.

Also, and I mean this: Send me your awesome-est spreadsheet tips. I am going to be unstoppable.

See you next week!

item.title: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Piccolo
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/dragon-ball-sparking-zero-episode-battles-guide-piccolo/

Dragon Ball Sparking Zero, Bandai Namco’s latest 3D fighter, has been released for PS5, Xbox Series X/S and PC. One of the game modes that players have developed a liking towards is Episode Battles. This game mode includes the iconic moments from the anime and allows players to explore branching storylines with never-before-scene scenarios. This Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles guide will cover all branching paths and alternate endings for Piccolo. 

Players should know that there are two types of branches: paths and alternate endings. Paths are complete changes in the timeline, with your decisions impacting future events. Alternate endings, on the other hand, are just different conclusions to existing battles of the series. Interestingly, some alternate paths also have Sparking! Episodes, which are original cutscenes created for the new moments. This guide will highlight all the branching paths and alternate endings for Piccolo and how to unlock them. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Saiyan Saga

Vegeta Vs Piccolo

The first alternate ending for Piccolo’s Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles arrives during his second fight in the Saiyan Saga. The ending is called Vegeta Vs Piccolo, and it can be unlocked if players can defeat Nappa quickly during ‘The Saiyans Attack’ mission, not giving him a chance to breathe. 

If you pull it off successfully, Piccolo defeats Nappa and doesn’t have to die defending Gohan. Vegeta kills off Nappa as he always does and then battles Piccolo. You will have to battle Vegeta during this segment. A win against Vegeta will take you back to canon events, with Goku and Vegeta’s fight concluding the Saiyan Arc. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Android/Cell Saga

A Mentor’s Guidance 

Next is a branching path for Piccolo in Dragon Ball Sparking Zero’s Episode Battles, which arrives during the Namek Saga. Players must defeat Frieza quickly during the Piccolo Returns to His Birthplace mission to unlock the’ A Mentor’s Guidance’ branching path. 

As Piccolo reaches Namek, he gains immense power by absorbing a fellow Namkeian Warrior, Nail. With the newfound power, Piccolo rushes to protect Gohan and Piccolo from Frieza. Here, players must battle Frieza in his 2nd and 3rd forms. To unlock the secret ending, you must defeat Frieza very quickly. Spamming Special Beam Cannons and Sparking! Mode attacks seem to be the only way.  

Succeeding in this task will unlock a new path where Frieza acknowledges Piccolo’s strength. You’ll battle Frieza in his final form until the battle ends. However, the end shows Piccolo struggling against Frieza, and Goku arrives later to save the day. All events that follow are similar to the anime, but Piccolo is dissatisfied with his lack of strength and wants to save Namek and Goku. Hence, Piccolo increased his training so he would not be in the same situation again. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Buu Saga

Backing Up Goku 

The ‘A Mentor’s Guidance’ path connects to the anime storyline but branches further in the Cell Saga. During the ‘Faint Unease’ mission, Goku seems to be struggling with the Androids, and you are offered a decision: either ‘Continue to observe the battle’ or ‘Help Out Goku’. If you continue to observe, the anime’s events will play out. However, if you decide to step in, Piccolo will join the fight against Android 19 and 20 to save Goku.  

Here, you will need to defeat Android 19. After the match, Goku doesn’t faint due to his heart disease as he usually does, but he still senses an issue settling in. Goku is rendered useless during this timeline as he cannot fight due to the growing virus, and the medicine can’t be used until the virus completely takes over. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Goku Super Saga

Training Gohan

Hence, he requests Piccolo to train Gohan in the Hyperbolic Time Chamber. However, before they can enter for training, Piccolo must battle against Cell, who has just absorbed Android 17. Here, you need to battle Cell’s second form. Goku comes to help, which allows Piccolo and Gohan to escape and train in the Hyperbolic Time Chamber. Here, you will fight Kid Gohan and have the option to train his mind or body. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero: Gohan Black Guide

Cell Games

Then came the Cell Games; this time, Piccolo was ready to take the mantle of Cell’s first opponent. Here, you must fight Perfect Cell. Piccolo puts up a tough fight but isn’t strong enough. He starts getting beaten up to a pulp by Cell, and that’s when Gohan jumps in. 

Gohan is enraged after seeing his mentor beaten and transforms into Super Saiyan 2. He brings the fight to Cell and shows him who the boss is. The rest of the events are a bit different from the anime storyline. Gohan does get his guard down, but his training with Piccolo allows him to calm down. Gohan asks Cell to surrender but enraged by this request; Cell tries to explode Earth. Goku teleports away with Cell and sacrifices himself. 

Now Gohan is powerless against Cell and needs to recover. To give him that chance, Piccolo again jumps into battle, handling Cell until Gohan is ready. A new Sparking Episode will play if you beat Cell in this mission. Gohan will launch his Kamehameha, but this time, instead of Goku coming to help, Gohan uses Piccolo’s training to overcome Cell. Piccolo also plays a hand in tipping the scales over to Gohan’s side during the final clash. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Gohan Cell Saga

Pride of a Champion

For this Piccolo Alternate ending in Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battle, you must complete an objective during the ‘Android 17’ mission. Piccolo winds up battling against Android 17, and Cell interferes to absorb Android 17. A new ending plays out if you defeat both characters in this battle. 

In this ending, Piccolo defeats Cell and overpowers Android 17. Looking at his strength, the Androids run away, and Cell is taken out for good. Finally, Piccolo saves the day but wants to continue training with Gohan to become even stronger. 

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Gohan Buu Saga

Related: Dragon Ball Sparking Zero Episode Battles Guide: Gohan Super Saga

If you are new to the game, check out the Attack, Movement and Defense guides. These are all the branching paths and alternate endings for Piccolo in Dragon Ball Sparking Zero’s Episode Battles. Which one is your favourite? Let us know in the comments or our new community forum!

For more Insider Gaming, check out our official Guides Hub. And don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Two Until Dawn stars separately tease a sequel is on the way
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/two-until-dawn-stars-separately-tease-a-sequel-is-on-the-way

Two stars of Supermassive's teen slasher horror Until Dawn have given our strongest hint yet that a sequel could be on the way.

Hayden Panettiere, who played Sam Giddings, and Peter Stormare, who plays Dr Hill, have each separately teased that a follow-up is coming, with Panettiere acknowledging in an interview that "they going further [with the franchise]".

Stormare, on the other hand, posted an image to his Instagram stories that says, "Until Dawn sequel confirmed with the remake?"

"Until Dawn has been around for years and years now. I think people love it," Panettiere said in a new bonus video.

"And the fact that they are going further with it says that there's a want for it."

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Peter Stormare, Dr. Hill in Until Dawn, heavily implies a sequel is happening in his Instagram Story
byu/Bartman013 inGamingLeaksAndRumours

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Whilst right now we can only take this as unsubstantiated rumours, both Stormare and Panettiere's comments are further bolstered by the remake's new ending, which also heavily implies a sequel is coming.

In related news, the movie adaptation of Supermassive's Until Dawn horror wrapped filming last week.

Director David F. Sandberg shared the news on his Instagram account, saying "we made it until dawn! That’s a wrap on #UntilDawnMovie".
